“In this place will I abide, and my heirs, unto the ending of the world.”

Over all his works a dark smoke hung and wrapped itself about the sides of Orthanc.

“Beregond, if you can, do something to stop any dreadful thing from happening.”
—Pippin
“The Realm of Sauron is ended forever!”

On the growing of vegetables, especially potatoes, Master Hamfast Gamgee was recognized as the leading authority by all in the neighborhood.
“Ónen i-Estel Edain, ú-chebin estel anim.”

“I hope they haven’t forgotten how to fight.”
—Gimli

NA
NA
“If indeed you look only, as you say, for records of ancient days and the beginnings of the City, read on!”
NA
“You may triumph on the field, for a day. But against the Power that now arises there is no victory.”
NA

She seemed tall beyond measurement, and beautiful beyond enduring, terrible and worshipful.

“This is worse than Mordor! Much worse, in a way. It comes home to you, as they say, because it is a home, and you remember it before it was all ruined.”
—Sam
NA
He hated the Ring and loved it, as he hated and loved himself.
NA
NA
NA

“We must hasten. The beacons of Gondor are alight. War is kindled.”
—Gandalf
NA
“No Dwarf could be unmoved by such loveliness.”
NA
The Mûmakil of Harad were great beasts, like moving houses, capable of dragging huge towers and engines to war.
From afar, Arwen watched over Aragorn, and in hope, she made for him a great and kingly standard.
“Boom, boom, rumboom, boorar, boom boom, dahrar boom boom, dahrar boom…”
His name, of course, was Proudfoot.

“None of the Orcs will ever return out of Lórien.”
—Haldir
“Now you must be brought before the Lord and the Lady.”
NA

“Whereas the light perceives the very heart of the darkness, its own secret has not been discovered.”
—Haldir
NA
The habit of building farmhouses and barns began among the inhabitants of the Marish down by the Brandywine.
NA
A shrill yell went up—they had been seen. There was a ring and clash of steel.

NA
NA
“Long have I wandered by roads forgotten, seeking the house of Elrond.”
NA
NA
NA
“There are but two courses: to hide the Ring forever; or to unmake it.”
“The last Steward of Gondor begs leave to surrender his office.”
“So it’s begun at last! I’ve been itching for trouble all this year.”
“A sword-day, a red day, ere the sun rises! Ride now, ride now! Ride to Gondor!”

Under the boughs of Mirkwood, there was deadly strife of Elves and evil beings.

“Is it not said that no foe has ever taken the Hornburg, if men defended it?”
—Aragorn

“The Dwarves tell no tale; but even as mithril was the foundation of their wealth, so also it was their destruction.”
—Gandalf
“I go my own way, but your way may go along with mine for a while.”

“Rivendell is a perfect house, whether you like food or sleep or storytelling or singing, or a pleasant mixture of them all.”
—Bilbo
While the power of Sauron grew, light and living things forsook his borders.

Aragorn took the green stone and held it up, and there came a green fire from his hand.
The way out lay across a slender bridge of stone. It was an ancient defense of the Dwarves that could only be traversed in single file.
NA
All that has been wrought by those who wield the Three will turn to their undoing, and their minds and hearts will become revealed to Sauron, if he regains the One.

“Few now have the skill in healing to match such evil weapons.”
—Strider
NA

“My heart rejoices; for you, Estel, shall be among the great whose valor will destroy the Shadow.”
—Arwen

“Narsil was broken and its light extinguished, and it has not yet been forged again.”
—Elrond

On the slab runes were deeply graven:
BALIN
SON OF FUNDIN
LORD OF MORIA
There loomed against the westward stars a dark black shape: a great barrow stood there.
Grey ruins falling into darkness, even with sunlight still shining in the sky.

“Evil things came forth, and they took Minas Ithil and abode in it, and they made it into a place of dread; it is now called Minas Morgul, the Tower of Sorcery.”
—Elrond
The hall was long and wide and filled with shadows. Mighty pillars upheld its lofty roof.
NA
Amon Sûl they called it. It was burned and broken, and nothing remains of it now but a tumbled ring, like a rough crown on the old hill’s head.
NA

“Let others a journey new begin,
But I at last with weary feet
Will turn towards the lighted inn,
My evening-rest and sleep to meet.”
—Bilbo’s song
It was popularly believed, as local legend, that the Hill at Bag End was full of tunnels stuffed with treasure.

“I stand in the place of the Steward of Gondor, and it is mine to think first of its people. Gondor must be protected.”
—Prince Imrahil
The chief city of the Kings of Men was Osgiliath, Citadel of the Stars. Now it is deserted, and in its ruins shadows walk.
Beyond, in the great fief of Belfalas, dwelt Prince Imrahil in his castle of Dol Amroth by the sea.

“We shall meet bitter cold, if not worse, before we come down on the other side. It will not help us to keep so secret that we are frozen to death.”
—Boromir
The Brandywine flowed slow and broad before them. A large flat ferry-boat was moored beside the landing.

“The Road goes ever on and on,
Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
And I must follow, if I can.”
—Frodo’s song

“This is the Window of the Sunset, fairest of all the falls of Ithilien, land of many fountains.”
—Faramir
The keep was called the Hornburg, for a trumpet sounded upon the tower echoed in the Deep behind, as if armies long-forgotten were issuing to war from caves beneath the hills.

“All dead, all rotten. Elves and Men and Orcs. There was a great battle here long ago, yes.”
—Gollum

“But I am going to Mordor,” said Frodo.
“I know that well enough,” said Sam. “Of course you are. And I’m coming with you.”
Pippin thought he saw groves of trees moving. Could it be that the trees of Fangorn were awake, and the forest was rising, marching over the hills to war?

—Boromir

“The Road goes ever on and on,
Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
And I must follow, if I can.”
—Frodo’s song

“This is the Window of the Sunset, fairest of all the falls of Ithilien, land of many fountains.”
—Faramir
The keep was called the Hornburg, for a trumpet sounded upon the tower echoed in the Deep behind, as if armies long-forgotten were issuing to war from caves beneath the hills.

“All dead, all rotten. Elves and Men and Orcs. There was a great battle here long ago, yes.”
—Gollum

“But I am going to Mordor,” said Frodo.
“I know that well enough,” said Sam. “Of course you are. And I’m coming with you.”
Pippin thought he saw groves of trees moving. Could it be that the trees of Fangorn were awake, and the forest was rising, marching over the hills to war?

NA
Before all went Aragorn with the Flame of the West—Andúril, like a new fire kindled, Narsil reforged as deadly as of old. And upon his brow was the Star of Elendil.

“Who can now hold the fords when the King of the Nine Riders comes?”
—Frodo

“Go! If you trouble us again, you will regret it.”
—Merry

“Hope he rekindled, and in hope ended; over death, over dread, over doom lifted out of loss, out of life, unto long glory.”
—Eulogy to Théoden

“The houses of the dead are no places for the living.”
—Gandalf
NA

“There we sat high up above the floods and watched the drowning of Isengard.”
—Pippin

“What roads would any dare to tread if the Dúnedain were all gone into the grave?”
—Aragorn
“The world is full enough of hurts and mischances without wars to multiply them.”
The one small garden of a free gardener was all Sam’s need and due, not a garden swollen to a realm; his own hands to use, not the hands of others to command.
NA
NA
In a twinkling the table was laid. There was hot soup, cold meats, a blackberry tart, new loaves, slabs of butter, and half a ripe cheese: good plain food, as good as the Shire could show.

“Is it not a law in the City that those who wear the black and silver must stay in the Citadel?”
—Gandalf

“Go now, Wormtongue, whither you will. But then, if we ever meet again, I shall not be merciful.”
—Théoden
NA
NA
Anything that Hobbits had no immediate use for, but were unwilling to throw away, they called a mathom. Their dwellings were apt to become rather crowded with mathoms.
NA
NA
“The enemy is at hand! We loosed every arrow that we had, and filled the Dike with Orcs. But it will not halt them long.”
NA
The Forest of Drúadan was granted to Ghân-buri-Ghân and his folk, to be their own forever.

“Last night I told you of Sauron, the Dark Lord. The rumors are true: he has arisen again.”
—Gandalf

Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky,
Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone,
Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die,
One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.

“And in the night from Otherworld beyond the Sea there strong and free a storm arose …”
—Song of Eärendil

“A new Power is rising. Against it, the old allies and policies will not avail us at all. There is one choice before us.”
—Saruman

“There are older and fouler things than Orcs in the deep places of the world.”
—Gandalf
The Riders were overwhelmed: drowned in the roaring of the river as it carried them away.

“What aid have you ever brought, Stormcrow? And what aid do you bring now? It was aid from us that you sought the last time you were here.”
—Wormtongue
Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards, for they are subtle and quick to anger.

“The Great Ring shall go now to be an heirloom of the North Kingdom; but records of it shall be left in Gondor, lest a time come when the memory of these great matters shall grow dim.”
—Scroll of Isildur
NA
They looked east to the Shadow and west to the Twilight, and they plighted their troth and were glad.

“Smoke rises once more from Mount Doom. The power of the Black Land grows and we are hard beset.”
—Boromir

“That is the business of Wizards: Wizards are always troubled about the future.”
—Treebeard
Once or twice the travelers heard the rush and whine of swan-wings, and looking up they saw a great phalanx streaming along the sky.

Suddenly a song began: a cold murmur, rising and falling, grim, cold, heartless and miserable. The night was railing against the morning of which it was bereaved, and the cold was cursing the warmth for which it hungered.
NA

“We have found many of our folk lying slain as they fled thither.”
—Rider of Rohan
“Precious, precious, precious!”

It seemed to the tenders of the sick that on the Halfling and on the Lady of Rohan this malady lay heavily. Soon they began to fall down into the darkness, and as the sun turned west, a grey shadow crept over their faces.
They seemed like black holes in the deep shade behind them. Frodo thought that he heard a faint hiss as of venomous breath and felt a thin piercing chill.
“Curse the Isengarders! Uglúk u bagronk sha pushdug Saruman-glob búbhosh skai!”
Frodo was hardly less terrified than his companions; he was quaking as if he was bitter cold, but his terror was swallowed up in a sudden temptation to put on the Ring.

“But the Ringwraiths themselves cannot be so easily destroyed.”
—Gandalf

“Regiments of black crows are flying all over. I do not know what they are about, but I think they are spying out the land.”
—Gandalf

“They tried to pierce your heart with a Morgul-knife which remains in the wound. If they had succeeded, you would have become like they are, only weaker and under their command.”
—Gandalf

Even Sam’s vision in the Mirror had not prepared him. The Old Grange on the west side had been knocked down, and its place taken by rows of tarred sheds. All the chestnuts were gone. The banks and hedgerows were broken.
There are many evil and unfriendly things in the world that have little love for those who go on two legs.

“And there are some things, of course, whose side I am altogether not on: these burárum—these Orcs, and their masters.”
—Treebeard

“This is the hour when we draw swords together!”
—Aragorn
“How long is it since Saruman bought you? What was the promised price?”
From far away, now dim, now growing, now mounting to the clouds, there came a drumming rumble, a roar, a long echoing roll of ruinous noise.

“Here, lord, is Herugrim, your ancient blade. It was found in Wormtongue’s room. Many other things are there which men have missed.”
—Háma, to Théoden
NA
What could not a warrior do in this hour?

“But the Orcs have brought a devilry from Orthanc.”
—Aragorn
NA

“I have looked on Moria, and it is very great, but it has become dark and dreadful.”
—Gimli

“A time may come soon when there will be need of valor without renown. Yet the deeds will not be less valiant because they are unpraised.”
—Aragorn
The few survivors were rounded up in the woods, and those who surrendered were shown to the borders.

“I daresay there’s more truth in some of them stories than you reckon.”
—Sam
Of the seven Rings of Power the Dwarf-kings possessed, three Sauron has recovered, and the others the dragons have consumed.
NA
Out from the beleaguered hills, knights of Gondor, Riders of Rohan, and Dúnedain of the North drove against their wavering foes, piercing the press with the thrust of bitter spears.
NA
They began to throw missiles that passed right above the battlement and fell thudding within the first circle of the City.
A hundred ladders were raised against the battlements. Over the wall and under the wall the last assault came, sweeping like a dark wave upon a hill of sand.
To his dismay, he could not both fight and keep hold of his treasure.

Buckler and corslet, axe and sword,
And shining spears were laid in hoard.
NA

“Radagast has much lore of herbs and beasts, and birds are especially his friends.”
—Gandalf

“Radagast is, of course, a worthy Wizard, a master of shapes and changes of hue.”
—Gandalf
The noise of bubbling waters came up from the foaming riverbed. Birds were singing, and a wholesome peace lay on the land.
Suddenly as they drew nearer, a terrific baying and barking broke out, and a loud voice was heard shouting: “Grip! Fang! Wolf! Come on, lads!”

“I sang of leaves, of leaves of gold, and leaves of gold there grew:
Of wind I sang, a wind there came and in
the branches blew.”

“The Three Rings of the Elves were not made as weapons of war or conquest—that is not their power. Those who made them did not desire strength or domination or hoarded wealth, but understanding, making, and healing, to preserve all things unstained.”
—Elrond

“In Dwimordene, in Lórien
Seldom have walked the feet of Men,
Few mortal eyes have seen the light
That lies there ever, long and bright.
Galadriel! Galadriel!”

“Do not think that only by singing amid the trees, nor even by the slender arrows of Elven- bows, is this land of Lothlórien maintained and defended against its Enemy.”
—Galadriel
NA

“Elves seldom give unguarded advice, for advice is a dangerous gift, even from the wise to the wise.”
—Gildor

“The leaves were long, the grass was green,
The hemlock-umbels tall and fair,
And in the glade a light was seen
Of stars in shadow shimmering.”
—Tale of Tinúviel

“It’s a dangerous business, Frodo, going out of your door. You step into the Road, and if you don’t keep your feet, there is no knowing where you might be swept off to.”
—Bilbo
NA
NA
Ent the earthborn, old as mountains.

“Sing hey! for the bath at close of day
that washes the weary mud away!
A loon is he that will not sing:
O! Water Hot is a noble thing!”
—The Bath Song

“Do not let your hearts be troubled. Even now, there is hope left.”
—Galadriel
NA
NA

“Huorns began to move south, as soon as the gates were shut again. Their business was with Orcs I think.”
—Merry
NA
They do not fear the Ringwraiths, for those who have dwelt in the Blessed Realm live at once in both worlds, and against both the Seen and the Unseen they have great power.

“There are no trees like the trees of that land.
For in the autumn their leaves fall not, but turn to gold.”
—Legolas
NA
All through the winter Sam remained as patient as he could. Spring surpassed his wildest hopes.
NA

“I have seen three ages in the West of the world, and many defeats, and many fruitless victories.”
—Elrond
Sam planted the little silver nut in the Party Field where the tree had once been, and he wondered what would come of it.
“Learn now the lore of Living Creatures!”
“Lembas is more strengthening than any food made by Men.”

“Elves are wondrous fair to look upon, or so ‘tis said.”
—Faramir
NA
There was a roar and a great confusion of noise. Fires leaped up and licked the roof. The throbbing grew to a great tumult, and the Mountain shook.

“The power of their master is in them, and they stand or fall by him.”
—Gandalf
The swift growth of the wild with briar and eglantine and trailing clematis was already drawing a veil over this place.
Umbar was a refuge for all the enemies of Gondor—a threat to its coastlands and to all traffic on the sea.
Soon the rabbits were cut up and lying simmering in their pans with the bunched herbs.
“That’s your tone, is it? Change it, or we’ll change it for you. You little folk are getting too uppish.”
“There is food in the wild. You need not be afraid of starving before winter comes.”

There rose a huge shape of shadow, impenetrable, lightning-crowned, filling all the sky. Enormous it reared above the world, terrible but impotent: for even as it leaned over them, a great wind took it, and it was all blown away.

“Magic rings are, well, magical; and they are rare and curious.”
—Gandalf

“When it turns round the black rock, you’ll see it. Suddenly you’ll see it above you, and you’ll want to hide.”
—Gollum
Gandalf’s fame in the Shire was due mainly to his skill with fires, smokes, and lights.

“The Ñoldor, perhaps Fëanor himself, wrought the palantíri in days so long ago that the time cannot be measured in years.”
—Gandalf
NA
NA
NA
NA

“The strongest must seek a way, say you? But I say: let a plowman plow, but choose an otter for swimming, and choose an Elf for running light over grass and leaf.”
—Legolas

The years had gnawed at it, and violent hands had maimed it. Its head was gone, and in its place was set in mockery a round rough-hewn stone, rudely painted in the likeness of a grinning face with one large eye in the midst of its forehead.
Each cloak was fastened about the neck with a brooch like a green leaf veined with silver.

In the Second Age, Sauron was not yet evil to behold, and the Elven-smiths of Eregion received his aid and grew mighty in craft, whereas he learned all their secrets, and betrayed them, and forged secretly in the Mountain of Fire the One Ring to be their master.
Faramir and Éowyn stood forth and set hand in hand; and all there drank to them and were glad.

“Thus is the friendship of the Mark and of Gondor bound with a new bond, and the more do I rejoice.”
—Éomer

“Grudgingly, Lord Denethor permitted me to search among his hoarded scrolls and books.”
—Gandalf
NA

“Seven stars and seven stones and one white tree.”
—A rhyme of lore

All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost;
The old that is strong does not wither,
Deep roots are not reached by the frost.
This was Frodo and Sam’s own country, and they found out now that they cared about it more than any other place in the world.

“Are these magic cloaks?” asked Pippin.
“I do not know what you mean by that,” answered the leader of the Elves.

“The palantíri of the Kings of Old: the name meant ‘that which looks far away.’ The Orthanc-stone was one, and it is beyond Saruman’s art.”
—Gandalf

“See you soon! I’ll bring you back an army of Tooks in the morning.”
—Pippin
The pleasant row of old Hobbit-holes in the bank on the north side of the Pool were deserted, and their little gardens that used to run down bright to the water’s edge were rank with weeds.

“In the morning, I shall ride to Edoras to the gathering of the Mark.”
—Théoden

“Shortcuts make long delays. The country is rough round here, and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish.”
—Pippin
The Shire had seldom seen so fair a summer, or so rich an autumn; the trees were laden with apples, honey was dripping in the combs, and the corn was tall and full.
The water of the Morgulduin was silent and steaming, but the twisting vapor that rose from it was deadly cold.
The dwellings of the Rohirrim lie under the wooded eaves of the White Mountains, hidden in mist and cloud.
The Hobbits of the Westfarthing said that one could see the Sea from the top of that tower; but no Hobbit had ever been known to climb it.
As Frodo put on the Ring and claimed it for his own, the Power in Barad-dûr was shaken, and the Tower trembled from its foundations to its proud and bitter crown.
The Númenóreans had become great mariners, exploring all the seas eastward, and they began to yearn for the West and the forbidden waters, longing for the immortality of the Elves.

“Now the great cloud hangs over all the land between here and the Mountains of Shadow; and it is deepening. War has already begun.”
—Errand-rider of Gondor

“The world is indeed full of peril, and in it there are many dark places; in all lands, love is now mingled with grief.”
—Haldir

When winter first begins to bite
and stones crack in the frosty night,
when pools are black and trees are bare,
‘tis evil in the Wild to fare.

“The oldest rowan-trees were planted by the Ents to try and please the Entwives; but they looked at them and smiled and said that they knew where whiter blossom and richer fruit were growing.”
—Quickbeam

“There’s some devilry at work in the Shire.”
—Sam
The sound of running and falling water was loud, and the evening was filled with a faint scent of trees and flowers, as if summer still lingered in Elrond’s gardens.
The road appeared lonely and forsaken, running down to empty ruins in the mist. But there was an evil feeling in the air.
At either end of the Bridge there was a great spiked gate, very gloomy and un-Shirelike.

“A great smoke rose about us, vapor and steam. Ice fell like rain as I threw down my enemy.”
—Gandalf
The Shadow departed, and the Sun was unveiled, and light leaped forth.
The light was grey, for the sun had not yet climbed over the black ridges of the Haunted Mountain before them.

“Beneath the Moon and under star
he wandered far from northern strands …
From gnashing of the Narrow Ice
where shadow lies on frozen hills.”
—Song of Eärendil

“As long as the Shire remains safe, I shall find wandering more bearable; somewhere there is a firm foothold, even if I cannot return.”
—Frodo
Legolas built a grey ship in Ithilien, and sailed down Anduin and so over Sea; and with him, it was said, went Gimli the Dwarf.
The Shirrif-house had only one story, narrow windows, and was built of ugly pale bricks, badly laid.

“I do not believe that the world about us will ever again be as it was of old. For the Elves may soon pass to the Sea unhindered and leave Middle-earth forever.”
—Haldir
NA
Merry stood at the foot of the green mound, and he wept.
Merry gazed at the Púkel-men with wonder and pity, as they loomed up mournfully in the dusk.
There at Pelargir lay the main fleet of Umbar, fifty great ships and smaller vessels beyond count.

Aragorn saw the River like a ribbon laid down to Pelargir, and beyond that was a light on the sky that spoke of the Sea. And Gandalf said: “This is your realm, and the heart of the greater realm that shall be.”

“You are in Rivendell, and you need not worry about anything for the present.”
—Gandalf

“I’m leaving; for somewhere where I can finish my book, perhaps. I have thought of a nice ending for it: ‘And he lived happily ever after to the end of his days.’”
—Bilbo

The houses and the holes of Shire-Hobbits were often large, and inhabited by large families. Sometimes many generations of relatives lived in comparative peace together in one ancestral and many-tunneled mansion.

“I have walked far to find these leaves; for this plant does not grow in the bare hills, but in the thickets away south of the Road.”
—Strider
At length they came to Weathertop; and it was then drawing towards evening and the shadow of the hill lay dark on the road.
NA
Behold! The power of Mordor was scattering like dust in the wind.
Before the shadows of evening were long in happier lands, they went on again with only brief halts until they had come to the very midst of the Dead Marshes.

“You should see the waterways of Dale, Frodo, and the fountains, and the pools! You should see the terraces and towers upon the Mountain’s sides!”
—Glóin
A land defiled, diseased beyond all healing—unless the Great Sea should enter in and wash it with oblivion.

Isengard began to fill up with black creeping streams and pools. The waters found their way down into shafts and spout holes, until at last Isengard looked like a huge flat saucepan, all steaming and bubbling.
The flowers glowed red and golden: snapdragons and sunflowers, and nasturtians trailing all over the turf walls and peeping in at the round windows.
The earth groaned and quaked. The Towers of the Teeth swayed, tottered, and fell down. The mighty rampart crumbled and the Black Gate was hurled in ruin.

“To Rivendell, where Elves yet dwell
In glades beneath the misty fell.”
—Merry and Pippin
The high throne was empty. At the foot of its dais, upon the lowest step which was broad and deep, there was a stone chair, black and unadorned, for the Steward of Gondor.
In the South, the realm of Gondor long endured, and for a while its splendor grew, its people building high towers and havens for many ships.

“Welcome to Caras Galadhon! Here is the city of the Galadhrim where dwell the Lord Celeborn and Galadriel, the Lady of Lórien.”
—Haldir

“But stream and pool is wet and cool: so nice for feet! We only wish to catch a fish, so juicy-sweet!”
